abstract: High bail amounts set for those arrested during Baltimore riots has led to defense lawyers, scholars and some judges to point to underlying problems in nation's money-based bail system; critics say system punishes poor defendants and serves to heighten racial and financial inequality, leading to poorer defendants being incarcerated before their trials for longer than necessary and at great cost, while wealthier defendants go free.
lead_paragraph: Money bail, entrenched in most jurisdictions, is under new scrutiny, with some critics decrying what they see as racial and financial inequities.

headline.main: When Bail Is Out of Defendant’s Reach, Other Costs Mount
headline.print_headline: Poor, Accused and Punished by Bail System
